head.title: Lysosome-Instructed Self-Assembly of Amino-Acid-Functionalized Perylene Diimide for Multidrug-Resistant Cancer Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Lysosome-Instructed Self-Assembly of Amino-Acid-Functionalized Perylene Diimide for Multidrug-Resistant Cancer Cells

Multidrug resistance (MDR) of cancer cells reduces chemotherapeutic efficacy by preventing drug accumulation in the cells through a drug efflux pump and lysosomal sequestration/exocytosis. Herein, to overcome such anticancer resistance, lysosome-targeted self-assembly of perylene diimide (PDI) derivatives is presented as a powerful strategy for effective and selective anticancer therapy. Stimulated by the lysosomal low pH, the amphiphilic PDI derivatives functionalized with amino acids (PDI-AAs) construct fibrous self-assembled structures inside the lysosomes, causing cancer cell apoptosis by lysosomal rupture. In contrast, negligible apoptosis was observed from normal cells by PDI-AA. The agglomerated fibrous assemblies were not removed by lysosomal exocytosis, thereby displaying a 10.7-fold higher anticancer efficacy on MDR cancer cells compared to a doxorubicin chemotherapeutic agent. The MDR-circumventing capability, along with high selectivity toward cancer cells, supports PDI-AAs as potential candidates for the treatment of MDR cancer cells by lysosome-targeted self-assembly.

div.p: Multidrug resistance (MDR) of cancer cells reduces chemotherapeutic efficacy by preventing drug accumulation in the cells through a drug efflux pump and lysosomal sequestration/exocytosis. Herein, to overcome such anticancer resistance, lysosome-targeted self-assembly of perylene diimide (PDI) derivatives is presented as a powerful strategy for effective and selective anticancer therapy. Stimulated by the lysosomal low pH, the amphiphilic PDI derivatives functionalized with amino acids (PDI-AAs) construct fibrous self-assembled structures inside the lysosomes, causing cancer cell apoptosis by lysosomal rupture. In contrast, negligible apoptosis was observed from normal cells by PDI-AA. The agglomerated fibrous assemblies were not removed by lysosomal exocytosis, thereby displaying a 10.7-fold higher anticancer efficacy on MDR cancer cells compared to a doxorubicin chemotherapeutic agent. The MDR-circumventing capability, along with high selectivity toward cancer cells, supports PDI-AAs as potential candidates for the treatment of MDR cancer cells by lysosome-targeted self-assembly.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Multidrug resistance (MDR) is one of the major hurdles reducing the efficacy of chemotherapy and is a major cause of cancer recurrence.
(1,2)
Evidence indicates that chemotherapeutic resistance is caused mostly by the overexpressed transmembrane protein of P-glycoprotein, one of the variants of the ATP-binding cassette superfamily responsible for pumping drugs out of the cell,
(3â7)
and by lysosomes that express lysosomal sequestration and exocytosis of chemotherapeutic agents.
(8)
To overcome MDR, many studies have considered modulating the expression of the drug-efflux pump via intracellular drug delivery.
(2,7)
Meanwhile, chemoresistance mediation via lysosomes is relatively unexplored, although lysosome-targeting cancer therapy is a promising strategy for not only the selective treatment of MDR cancers but also versatile cancer therapy. One of the strategies in lysosome-targeting therapy is lysosomal membrane permeabilization, involving the rupture of lysosomal membranes and release of hydrolytic enzymes of the lysosome into the cytosol, which can eventually lead to apoptosis of cancer cells. Some studies have attempted to induce lysosomal membrane permeabilization by external physical/chemical stimuli;
(5,8â11)
however, a simpler and more effective method is needed that will not impair normal cells.

One of the promising strategies in cancer therapy to circumvent MDR is the growth of suprastructures within or in the pericellular spaces of cancer cells, which causes cellular dysfunction or physical destruction of the intracellular organelles, leading to cancer cell death.
(12â16)
In situ self-assembly of small molecular building blocks can produce suprastructures in a controlled manner, thereby aiding effective anticancer therapy. In previous studies, enzymatic hydrolysis was employed as a biochemical trigger to inducing self-assembly of such molecular building blocks;
(17â19)
however, enzyme-instructed self-assembly is applicable only for specific cell lines. Therefore, as a versatile method to control cell fate, Ryu and co-workers proposed the intracellular organelle-localization-induced self-assembly scheme in which the inherent properties of the organelles were exploited to promote self-assembly.
(20)
Once organelle-localization-induced self-assembly is applied to lysosomes having high specificity and excessive accumulation of molecular building blocks, lysosomal dysfunction and subsequent lysosomal membrane permeabilization are effective methods to control the fates of the MDR cancer cells.

Herein, overcoming the anticancer resistances of MDR cancer cells
in vitro
is demonstrated using lysosome-targeted self-assembly, which exploits the lysosome lumen acidity (pH 4.5â5.5) of cancer cells as the stimulus to initiate self-assembly. Perylene diimide (PDI) derivatives with amino acids (PDI-AAs) were adopted as the molecular building blocks to examine their self-assembling capabilities in acidic conditions and efficacy of overcoming anticancer resistance in MDR cancer cells. Hydrophobicity and p
K
a
of the amino acids were observed to influence the self-assembly of PDI derivatives. Fibrous self-assembled structures were produced in the lysosomes of cancer cells to effectively control the fates of these cancer cells by lysosomal membrane permeabilization with considerably high selectivity. Particularly, PDI with 5-aminovaleric acid end groups caused apoptosis of MDR cancer cells with outstanding efficiency compared to chemical therapeutic agents.

div.h3: 2.1. Synthesis of the Amino-Acid-Functionalized PDIs (PDI-Asp, PDI-Î²Ala, and PDI-5AVA)
div.div:
The PDI derivatives were synthesized according to the standard condensation method reported in the literature.
(21,22)
In brief, a mixture of 1 mmol of perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic dianhydride, 2.2 mmol of an amino acid [
l
-aspartic acid, Î²-alanine (3-aminopropanoic acid), or 5-aminovaleric acid], and 15 g of imidazole was heated under nitrogen at 130 Â°C for 6 h. The reaction mixture was dissolved in H
2
O and filtered to retain the unreacted perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic dianhydride. The synthesized PDI derivatives dissolved in the filtered aqueous solution were precipitated by adding 1 M HCl. The precipitates were then filtered and washed with H
2
O and acetone twice to remove the excess imidazole. The collected dark red solid PDI derivatives were dried in a vacuum oven at 80 Â°C and maintained under dry conditions before use.

div.h3:
2.2. p
K
a
Measurement of the PDI Derivatives
div.div:
The p
K
a
value of each PDI derivative was determined by monitoring the change in the fluorescence intensity from the monomeric species. The fluorescence intensities (Î»
em
= 550 nm and Î»
ex
= 500 nm) of the 2 mL PDI derivative solution (10 Î¼M) was measured in the pH range of 2â12 with the addition of HCl at 25 Â°C. A sigmoidal fitting was conducted on the fluorescence data, and p
K
a
was determined at the pH of the half-maximal fluorescence intensity.

The critical aggregation concentrations (CACs) of the PDI derivatives at the pH of the lysosomal lumen (pH 5.0) were determined using pyrene as the fluorescent probe.
(23)
A 10 Î¼L solution of pyrene in ethanol (500 Î¼M) was mixed with 1990 Î¼L of the PDI derivative solution in acetate buffer (pH 5.0) at various concentrations, with the pyrene concentration fixed at 2.5 Î¼M. Under excitation at 335 nm, the fluorescence intensity ratio between the first (
I
1
; Î»
em
= 374 nm) and the third (
I
3
; Î»
em
= 384 nm) highest emission peaks (
I
1
/
I
3
) was measured. The
I
1
/
I
3
value was plotted against the concentrations of the PDI derivatives to determine the CAC at the intersection between the plateau and the tangent of the
I
1
/
I
3
value.

The static light scattering intensities were measured using a Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern Instruments Limited, UK) equipped with a HeâNe laser of 633 nm. Solutions of 10 Î¼M PDI derivatives in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.0) and acetate buffer (pH 5.0) were prepared and incubated for 1 day before conducting the measurements. The intensity ratios were proportional to the amount of fibrous self-assembled aggregates in the samples.

MCF-7/ADR, SNU-620/ADR-300, A549, and ARPE 19 (used as control) cell lines were used for the analysis. The MCF-7/ADR and A549 cells were incubated in Dulbeccoâs modified Eagleâs medium (DMEM) with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% antibioticâantimycotic (AA) at 37 Â°C; the SNU-620/ADR-300 cells were incubated in RPMI 1640 media with 10% FBS and 1% AA; the ARPE-19 cells were incubated in DMEM/F12 media with 10% FBS and 1% AA. The culture medium was changed every 2 days. Before the experiments, the cells were seeded at 1 Ã 10
5
cells in 1 mL of medium in collagen-coated cell plates. The cells were then incubated for 1 or 2 days, and the lysosomes were labeled with LysoView633.

div.h3: 2.6. Analysis of the Intracellular Uptake Efficiency and Apoptosis Ability
div.div:
The intracellular uptake of PDI derivatives was determined by monitoring their monomeric fluorescence. To calculate the concentration of the PDI derivatives inside the endosome and lysosome, excluding the decay of monomeric fluorescence originating from the self-assembly, the following procedure was conducted. The cells were harvested on cell plates at 37 or 4 Â°C and collected in a falcon tube; these cells were then suspended in 150 Î¼L of PBS, and about 200 Î¼L of alkaline cell lysis solution (0.2 M NaOH and 1% SDS with deionized water) was added to the cell suspension. After 30 min, the supernatant was collected by centrifugation and used for the experiments. The supernatant was diluted with 0.1 M NaOH solution, and the fluorescence intensities from the remaining PDI derivatives were monitored using a spectrophotofluorometer (RF-5301PC, Shimadzu Co., Japan; beam path = 1 cm, Î»
ex
= 500 nm). The linear calibration curves of the PDI derivatives were obtained by plotting the fluorescence intensities against the concentration of the PDI derivative.

The apoptosis ability of PDI derivatives was determined by flow cytometry using the Annexin V-cy5 kit. The A549 and ARPE-19 cells were treated with PDI derivatives for 24 h at concentrations of 5, 10, 25, 50, and 100 Î¼M. The MCF-7/ADR cells and SNU-620/ADR-300 cells were chosen as the model MDR cells showing resistance against doxorubicin. To test the apoptosis ability of the PDI derivatives for the MDR cells, the MDR cells were treated with doxorubicin or PDI derivatives at concentrations of 100 Î¼M. The cell apoptosis was then analyzed by flow cytometry after 15 min of incubation using the Annexin V-Cy5 kit under dark conditions. To clarify apoptosis ability of PDI derivatives, the A549 cells were treated with 100 Î¼M of PDI derivatives for 3 h and stained with Annexin V-Cy5 and DAPI solution (200 ng/mL). After staining, the cells were analyzed by an image cytometer (NucleoCounter NC-3000, ChemoMetec, Denmark); Î»
ex
: 405 nm, Î»
em
: 430/20 nm for DAPI, Î»
ex
: 630 nm, Î»
em
: 740/60 nm for Annexin V-Cy5.

div.h3: 2.7. Co-localization of PDI Derivatives and Lysosomes
div.div:
The co-localization of the PDI derivatives and lysosomes was achieved by confocal laser scanning microscopy. The A549 cells were incubated with 100 Î¼M of PDI derivative for 24 h, and the cells were stained with LysoView633 to view the lysosomes. After staining, the cells were imaged using a confocal laser scanning microscope (LSM880, Carl Zeiss, Germany); Î»

em
: 410â500 nm for DAPI, Î»

: 633 nm, Î»
em
: 700â759 nm for lysosome, Î»
ex
: 488 nm, Î»
em
: 500â600 nm for monomeric PDI derivatives, and Î»
ex
: 561 nm, Î»
em
: 600â670 nm for excimer PDI derivatives, respectively.

Cathepsin B activity was observed using the Magic Red cathepsin B detection kit. The A549 cells were first incubated with 100 Î¼M of PDI derivatives; cell samples were then retrieved twice after 3 h and 24 h incubation periods and stained using the detection kit to view the cathepsin B. The stained cathepsin B was observed using the aforementioned confocal laser scanning microscope; Î»

: 405 nm, Î»

: 633 nm, Î»

div.h3: 2.8. Intracellular Retention of Dox and PDI Derivatives
div.div:
To determine the intracellular retention of Dox and PDI-5AVA in MDR cells, the MCF-7/ADR cells were treated with 100 Î¼M of Dox and PDI-5AVA. After 3 h of incubation, the cell samples were washed with Dulbeccoâs PBS and incubated further for various durations (0, 0.5, 1, 3, and 5 h). The incubated cells were then stained with DAPI and imaged using a confocal laser microscope; Î»
ex
: 405 nm, Î»
em
: 410â500 nm for DAPI, Î»
ex
: 488 nm, Î»
em
: 500â600 nm for Dox, and Î»
ex
: 561 nm, Î»
em
: 600â670 nm for PDI-5AVA.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Amphiphilic PDI-AAs were examined for self-assembling behaviors under lysosomal acidic conditions. PDI is appropriate for the framework of amphiphilic building blocks because of its simple conjugation with other molecules and fluorescence properties owing to the aromatic units.
(10,24)
Three different amino acids, namely, aspartic acid (Asp),
(22)
Î²-alanine (Î²Ala),
(21)
and 5-aminovaleric acid (5AVA), were conjugated on both sides of the PDI to synthesize bolaform amphiphiles (
Scheme 1
). Amino acids having p
K
a
values (Asp: 1.88, Î²Ala: 3.55, and 5AVA: 4.27)
(25,26)
close to the pH of the lysosomal lumen were chosen so that the molecular building blocks of the PDI derivatives were sensitive to the acid stimulus. The synthesized PDI-AA derivatives are soluble in a weakly basic PBS solution (pH 7.4) because of electrical repulsion by the carboxylate groups on both ends. Once the PDI derivatives are exposed to an acidic environment under the p
K
a
of the amino acids, where protonation of carboxylate occurs, the electrical repulsions between the carboxylates is screened to form a robust 1D fibrous self-assembled structure through aromatic stacking of the PDI centers and hydrogen bonding between the carboxyl groups. These fibrous structures help destroy the target organelles, resulting in cell death (
Scheme 1
).

Scheme 1. Schematic of the Lysosome-Targeted Self-Assembly Using Amino-Acid-Functionalized PDIs with pH-Sensitive Self-Assembling Capabilities
a

figure.p:
a
Under physiological conditions, the PDI derivatives are present in monomeric/oligomeric forms to penetrate the cytoplasmic and lysosomal membranes. Fibrous self-assembling of the PDI derivatives is triggered by the lysosomal lumen acidity and destruction of the lysosome, leading to the deaths of MDR cancer cells.

div.div:
UVâvis spectroscopy was conducted to monitor the pH-triggered self-assembling behaviors of the PDI derivatives (
Figure
1
aâc). It is a facile method to monitor the aggregation of PDI-AA, although a more sophisticate method was developed for the thermodynamic analysis.
(27)
The PDI derivatives dissolved in PBS (pH 7.4) are in the oligomeric form and display characteristic absorption peaks at 545 and 500 nm, which are assigned to the vibronic 0 â 0 and 0 â 1 bands in the Ï â Ï* electronic transitions, respectively.
(21)
The ratios of these two peaks (
A
545
/
A
500
) are 1.02 (PDI-Asp), 0.48 (PDI-Î²Ala), and 0.51 (PDI-5AVA), suggesting the presence of PDI derivatives in oligomeric forms as compared to the typical values of the monomeric PDIs whose
A
545
/
A
500
values are greater than 1.
(21)
Under acidic conditions (pH 5.0), the peaks of the oligomeric PDI at 500 and 545 nm were fully diminished, and new broad peaks appeared around 460 nm, with a shoulder at 560 nm. These hypochromic shifts were attributed to the H-aggregation of the perylene cores, which support self-assembly of the PDI derivatives.
(28)
The fluorescence emission spectra of the PDI derivatives further verify the pH-induced self-assembly. The emission peak near 550 nm represents fluorescence from the monomeric PDI species at pH 7.4. Upon lowering the pH of the solution, the fluorescence was quenched by aggregation of the PDI derivatives, while new excimer emissions appeared around 650 nm (Î»
ex
= 560 nm), indicating the spatial proximities of the perylene units by agglomeration of the PDI derivatives.
(29,30)

div.p:
Figure 1. pH-induced self-assembly of the amino-acid-functionalized PDIs. (aâc) UVâvis absorption and fluorescence emission spectra of 10 Î¼M PDI derivatives under physiological pH and acidic conditions. (d) Determination of the p
K
a
of each PDI derivative. Normalized fluorescence intensities at 550 nm (Î»
ex
= 500 nm) were plotted with variation of the pH (inset: plots of the first derivatives of the normalized intensities to determine the p
K
a
values: PDI-Asp: 4.0, PDI-Î²Ala: 5.9, and PDI-5AVA: 6.4).

div.div:
Determination of the apparent p
K
a
values of the PDI derivatives is thus necessary to evaluate the self-assembling capability in the acidic lysosomal lumen that functions as the stimulus. The apparent p
K
a
values of the PDI-Asp, PDI-Î²Ala, and PDI-5AVA are 4.0, 5.9, and 6.4, respectively, as determined from the pH at which the fluorescence of the monomeric PDI species (Î»
em
= 550 nm) radically decays (
Figure
1
d). This difference in the p
K
a
of the PDI derivatives is due to the acidity and hydrophobicity of the amino acid motifs that guide the structural transitions from oligomeric to agglomerated species.
(31)
Differences in the p
K
a
values hence lead to self-assembly of the selected PDI derivatives under the lysosomal environment.

On the basis of the p
K
a
values, the self-assembling properties of the PDI derivatives were examined at pH 5.0 with the acetate buffer solution to simulate the pH of the lysosomal lumen. Fibrous self-assemblies were observed with the PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA after 1 day, while no recognizable assembled structures were found for PDI-Asp (
Figure
2
aâc). More fibrous structures were observed for PDI-5AVA than PDI-Î²Ala, showing large agglomerates of the PDI-5AVA nanofibers. Cryo-transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images support the formation of the fibrous assemblies, verifying that these fibrous structures were not caused by the drying effect during TEM sample preparation (
Figure S4
). From the cryo-TEM images, the average lengths of the PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA nanofibers were obtained as 220 Â± 36 and 332 Â± 37 nm with diameters of 8.2 Â± 2.8 and 11.7 Â± 2.0 nm, respectively, suggesting that different fibrous lengths of the self-assembly could be formed in lysosomes for different p
K
a
values. These sizes are smaller than those of fibrous PDI-Phe assembly,
(32)
showing that the hydrophobicity of the conjugated amino acids are crucial in determining the self-assembled structures.
(33)
The self-assembly of PDI-Asp occurred under more acidic conditions (pH 3.0) than that of the lysosomal lumen (
Figure S5
), as inferred from the p
K
a
value above. Note that the self-assembly of the PDI derivatives leads to gelation of the solutions once the concentrations of these derivatives are high enough (>5 mg/L). As expected for the self-assembling behavior, gelation was observed by lowering the solution pH below the p
K
a
value (
Figure S6
).

div.p:
Figure 2. (aâc) TEM images of the self-assembled PDI derivatives under weak acidic conditions simulating the lysosomal lumen (pH 5.0, 50 mM acetate buffer, and PDI-AA concentration 100 Î¼M). (d) Static light scattering intensities of 10 Î¼M of PDI derivatives at pHs 5.0 and 7.4. Data represent the mean Â± standard deviation (
n
= 3).

div.div:
Static light scattering was performed to verify the substantial aggregation of PDI-5AVA by acidification. The intensity of the scattered light, which is proportional to the number of self-assemblies, increased remarkably by lowering the pH from 7.4 to 5.0 (
Figure
2
d). Furthermore, the CAC also supports the self-assembling ability of the PDI derivatives depending on their p
K
a
values (
Figure S7
). Considered together, the TEM and light scattering results show that the PDI-5AVA and PDI-Î²Ala readily form fibrous self-assemblies (and even hydrogels) in the lysosomal lumen to significantly damage the lysosome, thereby enabling fate control of MDR cancer cells.

After verification of the pH-induced self-assembly, the PDI derivatives were applied to cancer cells to examine the organelle-localization-induced self-assembly
in vitro
. Confocal microscopy images show the formation of the fibrous self-assemblies in lysosomes of A549 cells after incubation with 100 Î¼M of PDI derivatives for 24 h (
Figure
3
a). The oligomeric and self-assembled PDI derivatives were distinguished by the difference between the fluorescence emissions from the oligomeric species and excimer emissions from the self-assembled ones. The PDI-Asp emitted fluorescence from the monomeric species in the lysosome only at high intensities, with negligible excimer emissions. On the contrary, PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA showed only co-localized excimer emissions from the fibrous self-assemblies, without fluorescence emissions at 550 nm. This corroborates the local supramolecular assemblies of PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA in the lysosomes by lysosomal pH stimulation.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Confocal microscopy images of A549 cells showing intracellular uptake of PDI derivatives. The blue-colored portions represent cell nuclei (Î»
ex
: 405 nm and Î»
em
: 410â500 nm) and the green-colored parts represent cell lysosomes (Î»
ex
: 633 nm and Î»
em
: 700â759 nm). The red and orange channels represent monomeric (Î»
ex
: 488 nm and Î»
em
: 500â600 nm) and self-assembled (Î»
ex
: 561 nm and Î»
em
: 600â670 nm) PDI derivatives, respectively. Scale bars represent 20 Î¼m. (b) TEM images of the MCF-7 cells showing self-assembled PDI derivatives after 24 h of treatment, which are indicated by arrows. (c) TEM images of PDI-5AVA-treated MCF-7 cells showing internalization through endocytosis. These assemblies are accumulated in endosome and massively aggregate inside the lysosome to initiate the lysosomal rupture.

div.div:
TEM images of the MCF-7 cells provided more explicit evidence of self-assembly. After 24 h of treatments, fibrous self-assembled structures of the PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA were observed in the lysosomes; further, swollen lysosomes and destroyed organelles, such as mitochondria, were observed distinctly (
Figure
3
b). Note that the TEM images of the MCF7 cells treated with PDI-Asp also show fibrous internal structures; however, these structures were likely to be driven by evaporation-induced self-assembly during the cell sample preparation procedures.
(34,35)
Further, the TEM images of PDI-5AVA-treated MCF-7 cells also support the formation of self-assemblies inside lysosomes with time (
Figure
3
c). At early stages, internalization of PDI-5AVA through endocytosis was observed and fibrous assemblies were structured in endosomes. Finally, massive aggregation of self-assemblies was stacked inside lysosome, and swollen lysosomes and destroyed organelles were observed.

The cellular uptake pathway and the driving force of the PDI derivatives were confirmed (
Figure S8
). The PDI derivatives exist in the form of oligomeric species,
(36)
and they are able to enter the cell by endocytosis. To confirm whether the driving force for the PDI derivatives to enter the cell is endocytosis, we performed endocytosis-inhibited cell uptake experiment. Various physical and pharmacological endocytic inhibitors can be used to identify endocytic pathways. Low-temperature (4 Â°C) treatment arrests all energy-dependent movement across the cell membrane including endocytosis.
(37)
By incubation at 4 Â°C, the fraction of cells containing PDI-AAs was reduced to 85.8% for PDI-Asp, to 76.6% for PDI-Î²Ala, and to 84.8% for PDI-5AVA. These results indicated that the endocytosis is the major driving force for cellular internalization of PDI derivatives.

Cancer cells are generally reported to have more numbers of lysosomes with larger sizes, superior cathepsin activities, and higher acidities than normal cells.
(1,11,30,38)
These distinguishable properties of the cancer cell lysosomes allow selective apoptosis of the cancer cells over normal cells via lysosome-targeted self-assembly of the PDI derivatives. The cellular uptake efficiencies of the PDI derivatives were quantified by fluorescence spectroscopy (
Figures S9 and S10
). The apoptosis abilities of the PDI derivatives were quantitatively analyzed using the Annexin V-Cy5 kit. Among the tested PDI derivatives, PDI-Asp showed the lowest apoptosis ability for both normal and cancerous cells (
Figure
4
a). This low cell apoptosis is known to be caused by the low p
K
a
of PDI-Asp, which impedes its self-assembly at the lysosomal pH (
Figure
2
d). On the contrary, PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA formed fibrous structures at pH 5.0 and showed outstanding apoptosis of the cancer cells with negligible effects on normal cells (
Figure
4
b,c). This apoptosis ability for cancerous cells increased with PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA concentrations, while the normal cells were only marginally affected even at increased concentrations. Note that PDI-5AVA showed higher apoptosis ability than PDI-Î²Ala, probably owing to the higher self-assembling property, thereby producing more nanofiber aggregates in the lysosomes. Furthermore, both these PDI derivatives exhibited outstanding selectivity toward cancer cells; for instance, a 13-fold higher apoptosis was observed in the cancer cells compared to normal cells when PDI-5AVA was applied. Such remarkable apoptosis abilities and high selectivity toward cancer cells show the feasibilities of PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA for controlling cell fate via lysosome-targeted self-assembly. In addition, Annexin V-DAPI double staining was performed to investigate the apoptotic stages of PDI derivatives (
Figure S11
). In A549 cells, the population of living cells was 75.9% for PDI-Asp, 62.1% for PDI-Î²Ala, and 58.5% for PDI-5AVA. Also, the population of early apoptotic cell appears to be 1.16% for PDI-Asp, 4.05% for PDI-Î²Ala, and 12.8% for PDI-5AVA, and late apoptotic cells appear to be 1.61% for PDI-Asp, 3.04% for PDI-Î²Ala, and 6.07% for PDI-5AVA. Consistent with previous results, PDI-5AVA showed highest apoptotic effects.

div.p:
Figure 4. Cell apoptosis by PDI derivatives as measured by FACS analysis. (aâc) Cell apoptosis abilities of PDI-Asp, PDI-Î²Ala, and PDI-5AVA; ARPE-19 (control) and A549 (cancer) cells were incubated with various concentrations of the PDI derivatives. Scale-controlled apoptosis with PDI-Asp shown in the inset of (a). (d) Cathepsin B released from the lysosomes to the cytosol in A549 cells after 3 and 24 h of treatment with PDI-5AVA. (Î»
ex
: 405 nm and Î»
em
: 410â500 nm for DAPI, Î»
ex
: 633 nm and Î»
em
: 700â759 nm for cathepsin B) All the scale bars represent 20 Î¼m. Studentâs
t
-test was performed to each treated group compared with control. *
p
< 0.05, **
p
< 0.01, and ***
p
< 0.001.

div.div:
As observed in the TEM images of the cancer cells (
Figure
3
b), lysosomal membrane permeabilization is the most plausible mechanism for cell apoptosis,
(9,11,20,39)
where the lysosomal membrane was destroyed by the aggregated fibrous assemblies of the PDI derivatives. The fibrous self-assemblies in lysosomes with massive aggregates readily cause stress and destroy the lysosomal membrane to elute cathepsin B into the cytoplasm, thereby leading to cell apoptosis. For verification of the lysosomal membrane permeabilization-driven cathepsin B release, the A549 cells were examined by confocal microscopy after treatment with PDI derivatives (
Figures
4
d and
S12
). Most of the cathepsin B remained localized in the lysosome after 3 h of treatment; however, after 24 h of incubation with PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA, cathepsin B diffusion was detected outside the lysosome. This indicates that the PDI derivatives require time to penetrate and self-assemble in the lysosome, clearly showing the release of cathepsin B into the cytoplasm by lysosomal membrane permeabilization. On the contrary, cells incubated with PDI-Asp and the control samples did not show any leakage of cathepsin B. Thus, the fibrous self-assemblies are observed to be necessary for damaging the lysosomal membrane and causing lysosomal membrane permeabilization.

These significant apoptosis selectivities toward cancer cells enable the treatment of MDR cancer cells, whose lysosomes are known to demonstrate cellular resistance against chemotherapeutic drugs, by enhanced lysosomal sequestration and exocytosis.
(40)
To examine the possibility of lysosome-targeted self-assembly as a strategy to overcome anticancer resistance, an MCF-7/ADR cell line, namely, MCF-7 breast cancer cells resistant to doxorubicin (Dox), was treated with PDI derivatives and the conventional chemotherapeutic agent of Dox for the purpose of comparison. After treating the MCF-7/ADR cells with PDI-5AVA and Dox for 3 h, the retentions of PDI-5AVA and Dox in the cells were monitored (
Figure
5
a,b). Dox was initially observed to be distributed throughout the cytoplasm but leaked out over time and only 18% of the Dox remained after 5 h. However, PDI-5AVA was well sequestered in the lysosome and preserved even after 5 h without a remarkable decrease in fluorescence intensity. The large agglomerations of the PDI-5AVA nanofibers remaining within the lysosomes presumably offered resistance against the enhanced efflux ability and lysosomal exocytosis of MDR cancer cells. The apoptosis abilities of PDI derivatives toward the MDR cancer cells were thus clearly differentiated from the control group treated with Dox (
Figure
5
c). Dox and PDI derivatives were treated in two MDR cells, MCF-7/ADR and Dox resistance gastric cancer cells (SNU-620/ADR-300). PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA induced considerable apoptosis of MDR cells, while Dox and PDI-Asp showed very low inhibition efficacies. Specifically, a 3.0â4.7 times increase of apoptosis for MCF-7/ADR was observed with PDI-Î²Ala and PDI-5AVA compared to Dox. Here, the outstanding MDR cancer cell apoptosis ability was observed to originate from the nanofiber self-assemblies of PDI-5AVA in the lysosome, which displayed resistance to lysosomal exocytosis.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, the lysosome-targeting organelle-localization-induced self-assembly of PDI derivatives was demonstrated as a promising strategy for cancer therapy by exploiting the acidity of the lysosomal lumen; this technique could be applied to MDR cancer cells for which chemotherapy may be ineffective. The rationally designed amino-acid-functionalized PDI self-assembling by stimulation of the cancer cell lysosome acidity, along with high specificity to cancerous cells over normal cells, was responsible for cancer cell apoptosis via lysosomal membrane permeabilization. The pH-sensitive self-assembly of PDI derivatives was shown to control cancer cell fates effectively without the need for other complicated procedures, including complex synthesis protocols or external stimuli to trigger self-assembly. Further, the cell apoptosis occurs at relatively low concentration of PDI-5AVA (IC50 = 28.5 Î¼M,
Figure S13
), being advisable for the practical purpose. The outstanding selectivity and efficiency for controlling MDR cancer cell fates indicate that PDI derivatives could be suitable cancer therapeutic agents, and
in vivo
tests may be needed in the future, with considerations for the improvement of cellular uptake efficiency.

Drug resistance in cancer: an overview
Housman Genevieve; Byler Shannon; Heerboth Sarah; Lapinska Karolina; Snyder Nicole; Sarkar Sibaji; Longacre Mckenna
Cancers
(
2014
),
6
(
3
),
1769-92
ISSN:
2072-6694
.
Cancers have the ability to develop resistance to traditional therapies, and the increasing prevalence of these drug resistant cancers necessitates further research and treatment development. This paper outlines the current knowledge of mechanisms that promote or enable drug resistance, such as drug inactivation, drug target alteration, drug efflux, DNA damage repair, cell death inhibition, and the epithelial-mesenchymal transition, as well as how inherent tumor cell heterogeneity plays a role in drug resistance. It also describes the epigenetic modifications that can induce drug resistance and considers how such epigenetic factors may contribute to the development of cancer progenitor cells, which are not killed by conventional cancer therapies. Lastly, this review concludes with a discussion on the best treatment options for existing drug resistant cancers, ways to prevent the formation of drug resistant cancers and cancer progenitor cells, and future directions of study.

Anticancer drug nanomicelles formed by self-assembling amphiphilic dendrimer to combat cancer drug resistance
Wei, Tuo; Chen, Chao; Liu, Juan; Liu, Cheng; Posocco, Paola; Liu, Xiaoxuan; Cheng, Qiang; Huo, Shuaidong; Liang, Zicai; Fermeglia, Maurizio; Pricl, Sabrina; Liang, Xing-Jie; Rocchi, Palma; Peng, Ling

Drug resistance and toxicity constitute challenging hurdles for cancer therapy. The application of nanotechnol. for anticancer drug delivery is expected to address these issues and bring new hope for cancer treatment. In this context, we established an original nanomicellar drug delivery system based on an amphiphilic dendrimer (AmDM), which could generate supramol. micelles to effectively encapsulate the anticancer drug doxorubicin (DOX) with high drug-loading capacity (>40%), thanks to the unique dendritic structure creating large void space for drug accommodation. The resulting AmDM/DOX nanomicelles were able to enhance drug potency and combat doxorubicin resistance in breast cancer models by significantly enhancing cellular uptake while considerably decreasing efflux of the drug. In addn., the AmDM/DOX nanoparticles abolished significantly the toxicity related to the free drug. Collectively, our studies demonstrate that the drug delivery system based on nanomicelles formed with the self-assembling amphiphilic dendrimer constitutes a promising and effective drug carrier in cancer therapy.

Core-shell hierarchical mesostructured silica nanoparticles for gene/chemo-synergetic stepwise therapy of multidrug-resistant cancer
Sun, Lijun; Wang, Dangge; Chen, Yu; Wang, Liying; Huang, Ping; Li, Yaping; Liu, Ziwei; Yao, Heliang; Shi, Jianlin

The design and synthesis of hierarchically nanoporous structures for the co-encapsulation and sequential releases of different cargos are still great challenges in biomedical applications. In this work, we report on the elaborate design and controlled synthesis of a unique core-shell hierarchical mesoporous silica/organosilica nanosystem, in which there are large and small mesopores sep. present in the shell and core, facilitating the independent encapsulations of large (siRNA) and small (doxorubicin) mols., resp. Importantly, the framework of the organosilica shell is molecularly hybridized with disulfide bonds, which enables the unique responsiveness to the reductive tumor microenvironment for the controlled releasing of loaded gene mols., followed by the subsequent doxorubicin release. The first released large siRNA mols. from the organosilica shell down-regulated the expression of P-gp in the cell membrane and reversed the MDR of cancer cells, thus enhancing the antitumor effect of subsequently released small DOX mols. from the silica core, and in such a synergetic way the MDR tumor growth can be efficiently inhibited. This work shows the significant advantages compared to the traditional small-mesoporous or large-mesoporous nanosystems for drug co-delivery.

Functional extracellular vesicles engineered with lipid-grafted effectively reverse cancer drug resistance
Liu, Jia; Ye, Zhilan; Xiang, Mengxi; Chang, Bingcheng; Cui, Jinyuan; Ji, Tiantian; Zhao, Lei; Li, Qilin; Deng, Yan; Xu, Luming; Wang, Guobin; Wang, Lin; Wang, Zheng

Multidrug resistance (MDR) is a key issue accounting for ineffectiveness of cancer chemotherapy. Numerous multifunctional nanocarriers have been developed to increase drug delivery efficacy and inhibit drug efflux for overcoming cancer drug resistance. However, limited success has been achieved in clinic because of nanocarriers' complicated multi-step fabrication procedures and their undesired side toxicity as well as potential immunogenicity. Here, hyaluronic acid (HA) functionalized extracellular vesicles (EVs) are generated as natural vehicles to efficiently deliver doxorubicin (DOX) and reverse MDR. The EVs isolated from noncancerous HEK293T cells (hEVs) reduce P-glycoprotein (P-gp) expression in drug resistant MCF7/ADR cells. To acquire tumor-targeting capability, hEVs are modified with lipidomimetic chains-grafted HA (lipHA) by a simple incubation. Owing to CD44-mediated cancer-specific targeting and P-gp suppressive capability, the HA-functionalized hEVs (lipHA-hEVs) remarkably promote the intracellular DOX accumulation in drug resistant breast cancer cells. In preclin. MDR tumor models, lipHA-hEVs deeply penetrate into tumor tissue and effectively transport DOX into tumor local, while eliminating DOX's systemic toxicity. Importantly,
[emailÂ protected]
inhibited MDR tumor growth by 89% and extend animal survival time by approx. 50%. Thus, our engineered tumor-targeting hEVs are promising natural carriers for overcoming cancer MDR.

8
Lysosomes as mediators of drug resistance in cancer
Zhitomirsky Benny; Assaraf Yehuda G
Drug resistance updates : reviews and commentaries in antimicrobial and anticancer chemotherapy
(
2016
),
24
(
),
23-33
ISSN:
.
Drug resistance remains a leading cause of chemotherapeutic treatment failure and cancer-related mortality. While some mechanisms of anticancer drug resistance have been well characterized, multiple mechanisms remain elusive. In this respect, passive ion trapping-based lysosomal sequestration of multiple hydrophobic weak-base chemotherapeutic agents was found to reduce the accessibility of these drugs to their target sites, resulting in a markedly reduced cytotoxic effect and drug resistance. Recently we have demonstrated that lysosomal sequestration of hydrophobic weak base drugs triggers TFEB-mediated lysosomal biogenesis resulting in an enlarged lysosomal compartment, capable of enhanced drug sequestration. This study further showed that cancer cells with an increased number of drug-accumulating lysosomes are more resistant to lysosome-sequestered drugs, suggesting a model of drug-induced lysosome-mediated chemoresistance. In addition to passive drug sequestration of hydrophobic weak base chemotherapeutics, other mechanisms of lysosome-mediated drug resistance have also been reported; these include active lysosomal drug sequestration mediated by ATP-driven transporters from the ABC superfamily, and a role for lysosomal copper transporters in cancer resistance to platinum-based chemotherapeutics. Furthermore, lysosomal exocytosis was suggested as a mechanism to facilitate the clearance of chemotherapeutics which highly accumulated in lysosomes, thus providing an additional line of resistance, supplementing the organelle entrapment of chemotherapeutics away from their target sites. Along with these mechanisms of lysosome-mediated drug resistance, several approaches were recently developed for the overcoming of drug resistance or exploiting lysosomal drug sequestration, including lysosomal photodestruction and drug-induced lysosomal membrane permeabilization. In this review we explore the current literature addressing the role of lysosomes in mediating cancer drug resistance as well as novel modalities to overcome this chemoresistance.

Self-Assembling Ability Determines the Activity of Enzyme-Instructed Self-Assembly for Inhibiting Cancer Cells
Feng, Zhaoqianqi; Wang, Huaimin; Chen, Xiaoyi; Xu, Bing
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2017
),

(

15377-15384
CODEN:

; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Enzyme-instructed self-assembly (EISA) represents a dynamic continuum of supramol. nanostructures that selectively inhibits cancer cells via simultaneously targeting multiple hallmark capabilities of cancer, but how to design the small mols. for EISA from the vast mol. space remains an unanswered question. Here we show that the self-assembling ability of small mols. controls the anticancer activity of EISA. Examg. the EISA precursor analogs consisting of an N-capped D-tetrapeptide, a phosphotyrosine residue, and a diester or a diamide group, we find that, regardless of the stereochem. and the regiochem. of their tetrapeptidic backbones, the anticancer activities of these precursors largely match their self-assembling abilities. Addnl. mechanistic studies confirm that the assemblies of the small peptide derivs. result in cell death, accompanying significant rearrangement of cytoskeletal proteins and plasma membranes. These results imply that the diester or diamide derivs. of the D-tetrapeptides self-assemble pericellularly, as well as intracellularly, to result in cell death. As the first case to correlate thermodn. properties (e.g., self-assembling ability) of small mols. with the efficacy of a mol. process against cancer cells, this work provides an important insight for developing a mol. dynamic continuum for potential cancer therapy, as well as understanding the cytotoxicity of pathogenic assemblies.

Targeted crystallization of mixed-charge nanoparticles in lysosomes induces selective death of cancer cells
Borkowska, Magdalena; Siek, Marta; Kolygina, Diana V.; Sobolev, Yaroslav I.; Lach, Slawomir; Kumar, Sumit; Cho, Yoon-Kyoung; Kandere-Grzybowska, Kristiana; Grzybowski, Bartosz A.

Nature Research

Abstr.: Lysosomes have become an important target for anticancer therapeutics because lysosomal cell death bypasses the classical caspase-dependent apoptosis pathway, enabling the targeting of apoptosis- and drug-resistant cancers. However, only a few small mols.-mostly repurposed drugs-have been tested so far, and these typically exhibit low cancer selectivity, making them suitable only for combination therapies. Here, we show that mixed-charge nanoparticles covered with certain ratios of pos. and neg. charged ligands can selectively target lysosomes in cancerous cells while exhibiting only marginal cytotoxicity towards normal cells. This selectivity results from distinct pH-dependent aggregation events, starting from the formation of small, endocytosis-prone clusters at cell surfaces and ending with the formation of large and well-ordered nanoparticle assemblies and crystals inside cancer lysosomes. These assemblies cannot be cleared by exocytosis and cause lysosome swelling, which gradually disrupts the integrity of lysosomal membranes, ultimately impairing lysosomal functions and triggering cell death.

We report on a simple carbohydrate amphiphile able to self-assemble into nanofibers upon enzymic dephosphorylation. The self-assembly can be triggered by alk. phosphatase (ALP) in soln. or in situ by the ALP produced by osteosarcoma cell line, SaOs2. In the latter case, assembly and localized gelation occurs mainly on the cell surface. The gelation of the pericellular environment induces a redn. of the SaOs2 metabolic activity at an initial stage (â¤7 h) that results in cell death at longer exposure periods (â¥24 h). We show that this effect depends on the phosphatase concn., and thus, it is cell-selective with prechondrocytes ATDC5 (that express â¼15-20 times lower ALP activity compared to SaOs2) not being affected at concns. â¤1 mM. These results demonstrate that simple carbohydrate derivs. can be used in an antiosteosarcoma strategy with limited impact on the surrounding healthy cells/tissues.

Enzyme-instructed self-assembly of small D-peptides as a multiplesStep process for selectively killing cancer cells
Zhou, Jie; Du, Xuewen; Yamagata, Natsuko; Xu, Bing
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(

),

(

Selective inhibition of cancer cells remains a challenge in chemotherapy. Here we report the mol. and cellular validation of enzyme-instructed self-assembly (EISA) as a multiple step process for selectively killing cancer cells that overexpress alk. phosphatases (ALPs). We design and synthesize two kinds of D-tetrapeptide contg. one or two phosphotyrosine residues and with the N-terminal capped by a naphthyl group. Upon enzymic dephosphorylation, these D-tetrapeptides turn into self-assembling mols. to form nanofibers in water. Incubating these D-tetrapeptides with several cancer cell lines and one normal cell line, the unphosphorylated D-tetrapeptides are innocuous to all the cell lines, the mono- and diphosphorylated D-tetrapeptides selectively inhibit the cancer cells, but not the normal cell. The monophosphorylated D-tetrapeptides exhibit more potent inhibitory activity than the diphosphorylated D-tetrapeptides do; the cancer cell lines express higher level of ALPs are more susceptible to inhibition by the phosphorylated D-tetrapeptides; the precursors of D-tetrapeptides that possess higher self-assembling abilities exhibit higher inhibitory activities. These results confirm the important role of enzymic reaction and self-assembly. Using uncompetitive inhibitors of ALPs and fluorescent D-tetrapeptides, we delineate that the enzyme catalyzed dephosphorylation and the self-assembly steps, together, result in the localization of the nanofibers of D-tetrapeptides for killing the cancer cells. We find that the cell death modality likely assocs. with the cell type and prove the interactions between nanofibers and the death receptors. This work illustrates a paradigm-shifting and biomimetic approach and contributes useful mol. insights for the development of spatiotemporal defined supramol. processes/assemblies as potential anticancer therapeutics.

Fibrils formed by proteins are vital components for cells. However, selective formation of xenogenous nanofibrils of small mols. on mammalian cells has yet to be obsd. Here the authors report an unexpected observation of hydrogel/nanonets of a small D-peptide deriv. in pericellular space. Surface and secretory phosphatases dephosphorylate a precursor of a hydrogelator to trigger the self-assembly of the hydrogelator and to result in pericellular hydrogel/nanonets selectively around the cancer cells that overexpress phosphatases. Cell-based assays confirm that the pericellular hydrogel/nanonets block cellular mass exchange to induce apoptosis of cancer cells, including multidrug-resistance (MDR) cancer cells, MES-SA/Dx5. Pericellular hydrogel/nanonets of small mols. to exhibit distinct functions illustrates a fundamentally new way to engineer mol. assemblies spatiotemporally in cellular microenvironment for inhibiting cancer cell growth and even metastasis.

Besides tight and specific ligand-receptor interactions, the rate regulation of the formation of mol. assemblies is one of fundamental features of cells. But the latter receives little exploration for developing anticancer therapeutics. Here the authors show that a simple mol. design of the substrates of phosphatases-tailoring the no. of phosphates on peptidic substrates-is able to regulate the rate of mol. self-assembly of the enzyme reaction product. Such a rate regulation allows selective inhibition of osteosarcoma cells over hepatocytes, which promises to target cancer cells in a specific organ. Moreover, the result reveals that the direct measurement of the rate of the self-assembly in a cell-based assay provides precise assessment of the cell targeting capability of self-assembly. This work, as the first report establishing rate regulation of a multiple-step process to inhibit cells selectively, illustrates a fundamentally new approach for controlling the fate of cells.

Yao, Qingxin; Huang, Zhentao; Liu, Dongdong; Chen, Jiali; Gao, Yuan

A review. Cancer remains one of the leading causes of death, which has continuously stimulated the development of numerous functional biomaterials with anticancer activities. Herein is reviewed one recent trend of biomaterials focusing on the advances in enzyme-instructed supramol. self-assembly (EISA) with anticancer activity. EISA relies on enzymic transformations to convert designed small-mol. precursors into corresponding amphiphilic residues that can form assemblies in living systems. EISA has shown some advantages in controlling cell fate from three aspects. 1) Based on the abnormal activity of specific enzymes, EISA can differentiate cancer cells from normal cells. In contrast to the classical ligand-receptor recognition, the targeting capability of EISA relies on dynamic control of the self-assembly process. 2) The interactions between EISA and cellular components directly disrupt cellular processes or pathways, resulting in cell death phenotypes. 3) EISA spatiotemporally controls the distribution of therapeutic agents, which boosts drug delivery efficiency. Therefore, with regard to the development of EISA, the aim is to provide a perspective on the future directions of research into EISA as anticancer theranostics.

The authors herein describe the tandem mol. self-assembly of a peptide deriv. (1) that is controlled by a combination of enzymic and chem. reactions. In phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), compd. 1 self-assembles first into nanoparticles by phosphatase and then into nanofibers by glutathione. Liver cancer cells exhibit higher concns. of both phosphatase and GSH than normal cells. Therefore, the tandem self-assembly of 1 also occurs in the liver cancer cell lines HepG2 and QGY7703; compd. 1 first forms nanoparticles around the cells and then forms nanofibers inside the cells. Owing to this self-assembly mechanism, compd. 1 exhibits large ratios for cellular uptake and inhibition of cell viability between liver cancer cells and normal liver cells. The authors envision that using both extracellular and intracellular reactions to trigger tandem mol. self-assembly could lead to the development of supramol. nanomaterials with improved performance in cancer diagnostics and therapy.

Mitochondria localization induced self-assembly of peptide amphiphiles for cellular dysfunction
Jeena M T; Palanikumar L; Kang Myoung Gyun; Park Sooham; Choi Huyeon; Kim Chaekyu; Rhee Hyun Woo; Ryu Ja-Hyoung; Go Eun Min; Kwak Sang Kyu; Kim Inhye; Jin Seon-Mi; Lee Eunji; Lee Seonik; Bae Sung Chul

.
Achieving spatiotemporal control of molecular self-assembly associated with actuation of biological functions inside living cells remains a challenge owing to the complexity of the cellular environments and the lack of characterization tools. We present, for the first time, the organelle-localized self-assembly of a peptide amphiphile as a powerful strategy for controlling cellular fate. A phenylalanine dipeptide (FF) with a mitochondria-targeting moiety, triphenyl phosphonium (Mito-FF), preferentially accumulates inside mitochondria and reaches the critical aggregation concentration to form a fibrous nanostructure, which is monitored by confocal laser scanning microscopy and transmission electron microscopy. The Mito-FF fibrils induce mitochondrial dysfunction via membrane disruption to cause apoptosis. The organelle-specific supramolecular system provides a new opportunity for therapeutics and in-depth investigations of cellular functions.Spatiotemporal control of intracellular molecular self-assembly holds promise for therapeutic applications. Here the authors develop a peptide consisting of a phenylalanine dipeptide with a mitochondrial targeting moiety to form self-assembling fibrous nanostructures within mitochondria, leading to apoptosis.

The crit. micellar concn. (cmc) of both ionic and non-ionic surfactants can be conveniently detd. from the measurements of UV absorption of pyrene in surfactant soln. The results on a no. of surfactants have agreed with that realized from pyrene fluorescence measurements as well as that obtained following conductometric, tensiometric and calorimetric methods. The absorbance vs [surfactant] profiles for all the major UV spectral peaks of pyrene have been found to be sigmoidal in nature which were analyzed according to Sigmoidal-Boltzmann equation (SBE) to evaluate the cmcs of the studied surfactants. The difference between the initial and the final asymptotes (ai and af, resp.) of the sigmoidal profile, Îa = (af-ai) and the slope of the sigmoid, Ssig been obsd. to depend on the type of the surfactant. The Îa has shown a linear correlation with the ratio of the fluorescence intensities of the first and the third vibronic peaks, I1/I3 of pyrene which is considered as a measure of the environmental polarity (herein micellar interior) of the probe (pyrene). Thus, Îa values have the prospect for use as another index for the estn. of polarity of micellar interior.

We have elucidated excimer-mediated intramol. electron transfer in cofacially stacked PBIs tethered by two phenylene-butadiynylene loops. The electron transfer between energetically equiv. PBIs is revealed by the simultaneous observation of the PBI radical anion and cation bands in the transient absorption spectra. The authors study the role of -NH2 and -COOH functional groups of complexing agents in H2O2-based slurries in controlling Cu removal rates. Slurries contg. complexing agents with 2 of the same functional groups (succinic acid: HOOCCH2CH2COOH, ethylenediamine: H2NCH2CH2NH2) and a complexing agent contg. one each of the functional groups (Î²-alanine: H2NCH2CH2COOH), all with the same C chain length, were studied. Along with dissoln. and disk polish expts., potential-pH diagrams were constructed for these 3 systems in the presence of H2O. The dissoln. and polish rates are consistent with the known activity of carboxylic acids (with -COOH groups) at acidic conditions and that of amines (with -NH2 groups) in an alk. environment. The obsd. trends in the removal rates with all these slurries are explained using potential-pH diagrams, UV/visible spectra, and electrochem. expts. When compared to glycine (H2NCH2COOH), Î²-alanine (H2NCH2CH2COOH) produced higher removal rates at acidic pH values and lower removal rates at alk. pH values. Finally, succinic acid and Î²-alanine-based slurries result in lower dissoln. rates and higher polish rates compared to glycine-based slurries at pH 4.

5-Aminovaleric acid (5AVA), an attractive bio-based carbon-5 building block for polymer synthesis, is produced from L-lysine. However, their structural similarity makes sepg. 5AVA from L-lysine challenging. The simulated moving bed (SMB), continuous chromatog. sepn. process provides a soln. with high productivity and low eluent consumption. Here, the effects of the mobile phase on the sepn. of 5AVA and L-lysine on a C18 column are reported. Pre-column derivatization using diethylethoxymethylene malonate enhanced the detection sensitivity and sepn. performance, which was strongly affected by the phosphate buffer pH. A 70/30 (vol./vol.) mobile phase of 20 mM phosphate buffer at pH 6.8 and acetonitrile showed the best sepn. performance in isocratic mode. The selectivity at adsorption equil. was detd. from pulse expts., and the optimal operating conditions of the SMB process were detd. from the equil. consts. of both components. The feasibility of sepg. 5AVA and L-lysine by the SMB process was confirmed with purity and recovery of greater than 99%. The SMB process using pre-column derivatization can provide the competitiveness of the bio-based chem. prodn. because sepn. processes typically contribute to more than 70% of the total prodn. cost.

Although it is commonly known that H-type PBI aggregates give rise to a broad, red-shifted excimer fluorescence with considerably longer fluorescence lifetimes than obsd. for the monomers, the underlying mechanisms of excimer formation and other relevant exciton dynamics in such Ï-stacked systems are still far from being understood. Perylene bisimides (PBIs) are one example of useful Ï-conjugated mols. that can be used in optoelectronic devices as n-type materials with strong visible light absorption. PBIs can self-assemble into a range of structures, but it is rare to be able to control the packing such that the same PBI can form either H-type or J-type aggregates. This is important because the cond. pathways and optoelectronic properties are directly affected by this packing. Here, we show that we can control the packing of a single PBI functionalized with an amino acid by a subtle change in pH. Under one set of conditions, H-type aggregates form a gel when the pH is decreased. At a slightly different set of starting conditions, J-type aggregates are formed, but they cannot form a gel when the pH is lowered. We show that films formed from the self-assembled structures have very different photoconductive properties.

Extracellular aggregated alpha synuclein primarily triggers lysosomal dysfunction in neural cells prevented by trehalose
Hoffmann Anna-Carin; Savitskiy Sergey; Kazman Aida; Xiang Wei; Minakaki Georgia; Menges Stefanie; Salvi Rachele; Klucken Jochen; Winkler Jurgen; Menges Stefanie; Savitskiy Sergey; Vicente Miranda Hugo; Mielenz Dirk
Scientific reports
(
2019
),

(
1
),

.
Cell-to-cell propagation of aggregated alpha synuclein (aSyn) has been suggested to play an important role in the progression of alpha synucleinopathies. A critical step for the propagation process is the accumulation of extracellular aSyn within recipient cells. Here, we investigated the trafficking of distinct exogenous aSyn forms and addressed the mechanisms influencing their accumulation in recipient cells. The aggregated aSyn species (oligomers and fibrils) exhibited more pronounced accumulation within recipient cells than aSyn monomers. In particular, internalized extracellular aSyn in the aggregated forms was able to seed the aggregation of endogenous aSyn. Following uptake, aSyn was detected along endosome-to-lysosome and autophagosome-to-lysosome routes. Intriguingly, aggregated aSyn resulted in lysosomal activity impairment, accompanied by the accumulation of dilated lysosomes. Moreover, analysis of autophagy-related protein markers suggested decreased autophagosome clearance. In contrast, the endocytic pathway, proteasome activity, and mitochondrial homeostasis were not substantially affected in recipient cells. Our data suggests that extracellularly added aggregated aSyn primarily impairs lysosomal activity, consequently leading to aSyn accumulation within recipient cells. Importantly, the autophagy inducer trehalose prevented lysosomal alterations and attenuated aSyn accumulation within aSyn-exposed cells. Our study underscores the importance of lysosomes for the propagation of aSyn pathology, thereby proposing these organelles as interventional targets.

Naturally occurring and synthetic short arginine contg. protein transduction domains (PTDs), including HIV1 TAT, poly-Arg and Antp, have been used to deliver a wide variety of macromol., biol. active therapeutic cargo into cells, including peptides, proteins, antisense oligonucleotides and liposomes, in vitro and to treat pre-clin. models of cancer and stroke. PTDs enter cells in a rapid, receptor-independent fashion. Recently, large TAT-fusion proteins (in excess of 30,000 Da) were shown to transduce into cells by fluid-phase macropinocytosis, a specialized form of endocytosis that is independent of caveloe, clathrin and dynamin. However, it remains controversial as to whether or not PTD peptides (1000-5000 Da) enter cells via macropinocytosis and/or through an unknown alternative mechanism. Due to strong ionic interactions with the cell surface, previous measurements of PTD peptide internalization were inaccurate. Cationic PTD peptides contg. variable nos. of arginine residues and conditions entered cells exclusively through macropinocytosis. In addn., no PTD peptide was found to enter cells at 4Â°, a long held assumption of transduction. Taken together, these observations provide a solid scientific basis for the development of novel biol. active transducible anticancer PTD peptide therapeutics.

can induce apoptosis through generation of reactive oxygen species and cathepsin-initiated apoptotic signaling pathways. Upon two-photon excitation,
[emailÂ protected]
show better penetrability, as well as higher inhibitory effects on cancer cell growth in both 2D cell and 3D multicellular tumor spheroid models. Our work provides an effective strategy for the construction of multifunctional imaging and phototherapeutic nanohybrids for the treatment of cancer.

40
What sustains the multidrug resistance phenotype beyond ABC efflux transporters? Looking beyond the tip of the iceberg
Alexa-Stratulat Teodora; Pesic Milica; Gasparovic Ana Cipak; Trougakos Ioannis P; Riganti Chiara
Drug resistance updates : reviews and commentaries in antimicrobial and anticancer chemotherapy
(
2019
),
46
(
),
100643
ISSN:
.
Identification of multidrug (MDR) efflux transporters that belong to the ATP-Binding Cassette (ABC) superfamily, represented an important breakthrough for understanding cancer multidrug resistance (MDR) and its possible overcoming. However, recent data indicate that drug resistant cells have a complex intracellular physiology that involves constant changes in energetic and oxidative-reductive metabolic pathways, as well as in the molecular circuitries connecting mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and lysosomes. The aim of this review is to discuss the key molecular mechanisms of cellular reprogramming that induce and maintain MDR, beyond the presence of MDR efflux transporters. We specifically highlight how cancer cells characterized by high metabolic plasticity - i.e. cells able to shift the energy metabolism between glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation, to survive both the normoxic and hypoxic conditions, to modify the cytosolic and mitochondrial oxidative-reductive metabolism, are more prone to adapt to exogenous stressors such as anti-cancer drugs and acquire a MDR phenotype. Similarly, we discuss how changes in mitochondria dynamics and mitophagy rates, changes in proteome stability ensuring non-oncogenic proteostatic mechanisms, changes in ubiquitin/proteasome- and autophagy/lysosome-related pathways, promote the cellular survival under stress conditions, along with the acquisition or maintenance of MDR. After dissecting the complex intracellular crosstalk that takes place during the development of MDR, we suggest that mapping the specific adaptation pathways underlying cell survival in response to stress and targeting these pathways with potent pharmacologic agents may be a new approach to enhance therapeutic efficacy against MDR tumors.

Drug resistance in cancer: an overview
Housman Genevieve; Byler Shannon; Heerboth Sarah; Lapinska Karolina; Snyder Nicole; Sarkar Sibaji; Longacre Mckenna
Cancers
(
2014
),
6
(
3
),
1769-92
ISSN:
2072-6694
.
Cancers have the ability to develop resistance to traditional therapies, and the increasing prevalence of these drug resistant cancers necessitates further research and treatment development. This paper outlines the current knowledge of mechanisms that promote or enable drug resistance, such as drug inactivation, drug target alteration, drug efflux, DNA damage repair, cell death inhibition, and the epithelial-mesenchymal transition, as well as how inherent tumor cell heterogeneity plays a role in drug resistance. It also describes the epigenetic modifications that can induce drug resistance and considers how such epigenetic factors may contribute to the development of cancer progenitor cells, which are not killed by conventional cancer therapies. Lastly, this review concludes with a discussion on the best treatment options for existing drug resistant cancers, ways to prevent the formation of drug resistant cancers and cancer progenitor cells, and future directions of study.

Anticancer drug nanomicelles formed by self-assembling amphiphilic dendrimer to combat cancer drug resistance
Wei, Tuo; Chen, Chao; Liu, Juan; Liu, Cheng; Posocco, Paola; Liu, Xiaoxuan; Cheng, Qiang; Huo, Shuaidong; Liang, Zicai; Fermeglia, Maurizio; Pricl, Sabrina; Liang, Xing-Jie; Rocchi, Palma; Peng, Ling

(
2015

(

),
2978-2983

PNASA6
; ISSN:
0027-8424
.
(
National Academy of Sciences
)
Drug resistance and toxicity constitute challenging hurdles for cancer therapy. The application of nanotechnol. for anticancer drug delivery is expected to address these issues and bring new hope for cancer treatment. In this context, we established an original nanomicellar drug delivery system based on an amphiphilic dendrimer (AmDM), which could generate supramol. micelles to effectively encapsulate the anticancer drug doxorubicin (DOX) with high drug-loading capacity (>40%), thanks to the unique dendritic structure creating large void space for drug accommodation. The resulting AmDM/DOX nanomicelles were able to enhance drug potency and combat doxorubicin resistance in breast cancer models by significantly enhancing cellular uptake while considerably decreasing efflux of the drug. In addn., the AmDM/DOX nanoparticles abolished significantly the toxicity related to the free drug. Collectively, our studies demonstrate that the drug delivery system based on nanomicelles formed with the self-assembling amphiphilic dendrimer constitutes a promising and effective drug carrier in cancer therapy.

Core-shell hierarchical mesostructured silica nanoparticles for gene/chemo-synergetic stepwise therapy of multidrug-resistant cancer
Sun, Lijun; Wang, Dangge; Chen, Yu; Wang, Liying; Huang, Ping; Li, Yaping; Liu, Ziwei; Yao, Heliang; Shi, Jianlin
Biomaterials
(
2017
),

The design and synthesis of hierarchically nanoporous structures for the co-encapsulation and sequential releases of different cargos are still great challenges in biomedical applications. In this work, we report on the elaborate design and controlled synthesis of a unique core-shell hierarchical mesoporous silica/organosilica nanosystem, in which there are large and small mesopores sep. present in the shell and core, facilitating the independent encapsulations of large (siRNA) and small (doxorubicin) mols., resp. Importantly, the framework of the organosilica shell is molecularly hybridized with disulfide bonds, which enables the unique responsiveness to the reductive tumor microenvironment for the controlled releasing of loaded gene mols., followed by the subsequent doxorubicin release. The first released large siRNA mols. from the organosilica shell down-regulated the expression of P-gp in the cell membrane and reversed the MDR of cancer cells, thus enhancing the antitumor effect of subsequently released small DOX mols. from the silica core, and in such a synergetic way the MDR tumor growth can be efficiently inhibited. This work shows the significant advantages compared to the traditional small-mesoporous or large-mesoporous nanosystems for drug co-delivery.

Functional extracellular vesicles engineered with lipid-grafted effectively reverse cancer drug resistance
Liu, Jia; Ye, Zhilan; Xiang, Mengxi; Chang, Bingcheng; Cui, Jinyuan; Ji, Tiantian; Zhao, Lei; Li, Qilin; Deng, Yan; Xu, Luming; Wang, Guobin; Wang, Lin; Wang, Zheng

Multidrug resistance (MDR) is a key issue accounting for ineffectiveness of cancer chemotherapy. Numerous multifunctional nanocarriers have been developed to increase drug delivery efficacy and inhibit drug efflux for overcoming cancer drug resistance. However, limited success has been achieved in clinic because of nanocarriers' complicated multi-step fabrication procedures and their undesired side toxicity as well as potential immunogenicity. Here, hyaluronic acid (HA) functionalized extracellular vesicles (EVs) are generated as natural vehicles to efficiently deliver doxorubicin (DOX) and reverse MDR. The EVs isolated from noncancerous HEK293T cells (hEVs) reduce P-glycoprotein (P-gp) expression in drug resistant MCF7/ADR cells. To acquire tumor-targeting capability, hEVs are modified with lipidomimetic chains-grafted HA (lipHA) by a simple incubation. Owing to CD44-mediated cancer-specific targeting and P-gp suppressive capability, the HA-functionalized hEVs (lipHA-hEVs) remarkably promote the intracellular DOX accumulation in drug resistant breast cancer cells. In preclin. MDR tumor models, lipHA-hEVs deeply penetrate into tumor tissue and effectively transport DOX into tumor local, while eliminating DOX's systemic toxicity. Importantly,
[emailÂ protected]
inhibited MDR tumor growth by 89% and extend animal survival time by approx. 50%. Thus, our engineered tumor-targeting hEVs are promising natural carriers for overcoming cancer MDR.

8
Lysosomes as mediators of drug resistance in cancer
Zhitomirsky Benny; Assaraf Yehuda G
Drug resistance updates : reviews and commentaries in antimicrobial and anticancer chemotherapy
(
2016
),
24
(
),
23-33
ISSN:
.
Drug resistance remains a leading cause of chemotherapeutic treatment failure and cancer-related mortality. While some mechanisms of anticancer drug resistance have been well characterized, multiple mechanisms remain elusive. In this respect, passive ion trapping-based lysosomal sequestration of multiple hydrophobic weak-base chemotherapeutic agents was found to reduce the accessibility of these drugs to their target sites, resulting in a markedly reduced cytotoxic effect and drug resistance. Recently we have demonstrated that lysosomal sequestration of hydrophobic weak base drugs triggers TFEB-mediated lysosomal biogenesis resulting in an enlarged lysosomal compartment, capable of enhanced drug sequestration. This study further showed that cancer cells with an increased number of drug-accumulating lysosomes are more resistant to lysosome-sequestered drugs, suggesting a model of drug-induced lysosome-mediated chemoresistance. In addition to passive drug sequestration of hydrophobic weak base chemotherapeutics, other mechanisms of lysosome-mediated drug resistance have also been reported; these include active lysosomal drug sequestration mediated by ATP-driven transporters from the ABC superfamily, and a role for lysosomal copper transporters in cancer resistance to platinum-based chemotherapeutics. Furthermore, lysosomal exocytosis was suggested as a mechanism to facilitate the clearance of chemotherapeutics which highly accumulated in lysosomes, thus providing an additional line of resistance, supplementing the organelle entrapment of chemotherapeutics away from their target sites. Along with these mechanisms of lysosome-mediated drug resistance, several approaches were recently developed for the overcoming of drug resistance or exploiting lysosomal drug sequestration, including lysosomal photodestruction and drug-induced lysosomal membrane permeabilization. In this review we explore the current literature addressing the role of lysosomes in mediating cancer drug resistance as well as novel modalities to overcome this chemoresistance.

Feng, Zhaoqianqi; Wang, Huaimin; Chen, Xiaoyi; Xu, Bing

Enzyme-instructed self-assembly (EISA) represents a dynamic continuum of supramol. nanostructures that selectively inhibits cancer cells via simultaneously targeting multiple hallmark capabilities of cancer, but how to design the small mols. for EISA from the vast mol. space remains an unanswered question. Here we show that the self-assembling ability of small mols. controls the anticancer activity of EISA. Examg. the EISA precursor analogs consisting of an N-capped D-tetrapeptide, a phosphotyrosine residue, and a diester or a diamide group, we find that, regardless of the stereochem. and the regiochem. of their tetrapeptidic backbones, the anticancer activities of these precursors largely match their self-assembling abilities. Addnl. mechanistic studies confirm that the assemblies of the small peptide derivs. result in cell death, accompanying significant rearrangement of cytoskeletal proteins and plasma membranes. These results imply that the diester or diamide derivs. of the D-tetrapeptides self-assemble pericellularly, as well as intracellularly, to result in cell death. As the first case to correlate thermodn. properties (e.g., self-assembling ability) of small mols. with the efficacy of a mol. process against cancer cells, this work provides an important insight for developing a mol. dynamic continuum for potential cancer therapy, as well as understanding the cytotoxicity of pathogenic assemblies.

Targeted crystallization of mixed-charge nanoparticles in lysosomes induces selective death of cancer cells
Borkowska, Magdalena; Siek, Marta; Kolygina, Diana V.; Sobolev, Yaroslav I.; Lach, Slawomir; Kumar, Sumit; Cho, Yoon-Kyoung; Kandere-Grzybowska, Kristiana; Grzybowski, Bartosz A.

Abstr.: Lysosomes have become an important target for anticancer therapeutics because lysosomal cell death bypasses the classical caspase-dependent apoptosis pathway, enabling the targeting of apoptosis- and drug-resistant cancers. However, only a few small mols.-mostly repurposed drugs-have been tested so far, and these typically exhibit low cancer selectivity, making them suitable only for combination therapies. Here, we show that mixed-charge nanoparticles covered with certain ratios of pos. and neg. charged ligands can selectively target lysosomes in cancerous cells while exhibiting only marginal cytotoxicity towards normal cells. This selectivity results from distinct pH-dependent aggregation events, starting from the formation of small, endocytosis-prone clusters at cell surfaces and ending with the formation of large and well-ordered nanoparticle assemblies and crystals inside cancer lysosomes. These assemblies cannot be cleared by exocytosis and cause lysosome swelling, which gradually disrupts the integrity of lysosomal membranes, ultimately impairing lysosomal functions and triggering cell death.

We report on a simple carbohydrate amphiphile able to self-assemble into nanofibers upon enzymic dephosphorylation. The self-assembly can be triggered by alk. phosphatase (ALP) in soln. or in situ by the ALP produced by osteosarcoma cell line, SaOs2. In the latter case, assembly and localized gelation occurs mainly on the cell surface. The gelation of the pericellular environment induces a redn. of the SaOs2 metabolic activity at an initial stage (â¤7 h) that results in cell death at longer exposure periods (â¥24 h). We show that this effect depends on the phosphatase concn., and thus, it is cell-selective with prechondrocytes ATDC5 (that express â¼15-20 times lower ALP activity compared to SaOs2) not being affected at concns. â¤1 mM. These results demonstrate that simple carbohydrate derivs. can be used in an antiosteosarcoma strategy with limited impact on the surrounding healthy cells/tissues.

Enzyme-instructed self-assembly of small D-peptides as a multiplesStep process for selectively killing cancer cells
Zhou, Jie; Du, Xuewen; Yamagata, Natsuko; Xu, Bing

Selective inhibition of cancer cells remains a challenge in chemotherapy. Here we report the mol. and cellular validation of enzyme-instructed self-assembly (EISA) as a multiple step process for selectively killing cancer cells that overexpress alk. phosphatases (ALPs). We design and synthesize two kinds of D-tetrapeptide contg. one or two phosphotyrosine residues and with the N-terminal capped by a naphthyl group. Upon enzymic dephosphorylation, these D-tetrapeptides turn into self-assembling mols. to form nanofibers in water. Incubating these D-tetrapeptides with several cancer cell lines and one normal cell line, the unphosphorylated D-tetrapeptides are innocuous to all the cell lines, the mono- and diphosphorylated D-tetrapeptides selectively inhibit the cancer cells, but not the normal cell. The monophosphorylated D-tetrapeptides exhibit more potent inhibitory activity than the diphosphorylated D-tetrapeptides do; the cancer cell lines express higher level of ALPs are more susceptible to inhibition by the phosphorylated D-tetrapeptides; the precursors of D-tetrapeptides that possess higher self-assembling abilities exhibit higher inhibitory activities. These results confirm the important role of enzymic reaction and self-assembly. Using uncompetitive inhibitors of ALPs and fluorescent D-tetrapeptides, we delineate that the enzyme catalyzed dephosphorylation and the self-assembly steps, together, result in the localization of the nanofibers of D-tetrapeptides for killing the cancer cells. We find that the cell death modality likely assocs. with the cell type and prove the interactions between nanofibers and the death receptors. This work illustrates a paradigm-shifting and biomimetic approach and contributes useful mol. insights for the development of spatiotemporal defined supramol. processes/assemblies as potential anticancer therapeutics.

Fibrils formed by proteins are vital components for cells. However, selective formation of xenogenous nanofibrils of small mols. on mammalian cells has yet to be obsd. Here the authors report an unexpected observation of hydrogel/nanonets of a small D-peptide deriv. in pericellular space. Surface and secretory phosphatases dephosphorylate a precursor of a hydrogelator to trigger the self-assembly of the hydrogelator and to result in pericellular hydrogel/nanonets selectively around the cancer cells that overexpress phosphatases. Cell-based assays confirm that the pericellular hydrogel/nanonets block cellular mass exchange to induce apoptosis of cancer cells, including multidrug-resistance (MDR) cancer cells, MES-SA/Dx5. Pericellular hydrogel/nanonets of small mols. to exhibit distinct functions illustrates a fundamentally new way to engineer mol. assemblies spatiotemporally in cellular microenvironment for inhibiting cancer cell growth and even metastasis.

Besides tight and specific ligand-receptor interactions, the rate regulation of the formation of mol. assemblies is one of fundamental features of cells. But the latter receives little exploration for developing anticancer therapeutics. Here the authors show that a simple mol. design of the substrates of phosphatases-tailoring the no. of phosphates on peptidic substrates-is able to regulate the rate of mol. self-assembly of the enzyme reaction product. Such a rate regulation allows selective inhibition of osteosarcoma cells over hepatocytes, which promises to target cancer cells in a specific organ. Moreover, the result reveals that the direct measurement of the rate of the self-assembly in a cell-based assay provides precise assessment of the cell targeting capability of self-assembly. This work, as the first report establishing rate regulation of a multiple-step process to inhibit cells selectively, illustrates a fundamentally new approach for controlling the fate of cells.
